NOTES:
Shorter sequences are most likely from sequencing bias, as in it didn’t sequence the whole gene so you get shorter versions of the actual gene. 
Sometimes this could also be due to assembly of the reads/contigs during de novo assembly of the transcriptome.
Isoforms definitely exist in biology, but isoforms detected from transcriptome assembly are sometimes not real and an issue with assembly itself.
To determine isoforms in transcriptome data, you look at the _i* at the end of the transcript id.
So those transripts you sent are all from different transcripts (‘genes’)
Isoforms of the same transcript would have the same transcript id, but different i*  at the end.
Like Gene 1_i1
And Gene 1_i2
Two different isoforms of the same gene/transcript
I am using gene and transcript interchangeably here. But transcript is what you get from transcriptomic data and you assume its transcribed from the gene.
